thread.title: It’s too early for the housing market to break out the bubbly
thread.title_full: It’s too early for the housing market to break out the bubbly - MarketWatch

author: By     Ruth Mantell
title: It’s too early for the housing market to break out the bubbly
text:
WASHINGTON (MarketWatch) — New home building sprang higher last month, but the lopsided gains were led by volatile apartment building, and the U.S. housing market still has much room for improvement, data released on Friday show.
Consider this: June’s growth in housing starts was due entirely to multifamily housing such as apartments and condos (buoyed by developers rushing to take advantage of an expiring New York City tax break ), while construction started on single-family homes slowed down, according to the U.S. Commerce Department.
Read more: Home builders rush to put up rental units at 28-year high
Just how strong is apartment construction? Starts in buildings with at least five units made up 41% of total new home construction in June — the largest share in 42 years — up from 33% a year earlier. Meanwhile, the pace of new constriction on single-family homes was 41% lower than the average rate over the three decades leading up to a 2006 peak.
Builders are responding to demand from individuals and families who are unwilling or unable to buy a single-family home. Apartment demand is so strong that landlords are able to keep cranking up rents far faster than the pace of overall inflation.
Also read: Consumer inflation on rise again — but slowly
“Construction in the multifamily segment has surged in the post-crisis years,” said Gregory Daco, head of U.S. macroeconomics at Oxford Economics. “Activity in the single-family segment still has much room for improvement.”
Builders are unlikely to maintain June’s breathtaking pace of apartment construction, and a strengthening employment market should further support sales of new one-family homes, economists said. That’s good news for the broader economy because building a single-family home creates more jobs than constructing an apartment unit.
“While builders and lenders benefit regardless of the type of construction, the economic benefit ... is significantly greater from single-family construction as opposed to multifamily units, particularly rental properties,” said Lindsey Piegza, chief economist at Stifel Fixed Income. “Single-family-housing activity results in additional spending and borrowing power as a result of equity building, which is not necessarily present in multifamily properties.”
Home builders, themselves, are quite optimistic about single-family-home sales. The economy is adding jobs at a healthy pace and mortgage rates are still low. Major publicly traded builders recently reported strong annual growth for new orders. However, there are also still headwinds for the single-family-home market, such as lenders’ strict credit standards.
Read more: Home-builder confidence stays at highest level in almost 10 years
More from MarketWatch
